facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 375 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 375 of 1959. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 12th August 1958 of Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 11 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 12th August, 1958, of the Assam High Court in First Appeal No. 11 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by WANCHOO J. on October 27, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. October 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: Election held in double-member constituency of Goalpara to Assam Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Assam High Court in an election matter. An election was held in the double-member companystituency of Goalpara

facts.text: Nomination papers filed on 19th January 1957 including by Anirara Basumatari, candidate for scheduled tribes seat.

anchor.surface_text: to the Assam Legislative Assembly. Nomination papers were filed on the 19th January, 1957, by a number of persons including Anirara Basumatari  hereinafter called the appellant .

facts.text: Nomination paper of Anirara Basumatari rejected by returning officer under s.7(b) of Representation of the People Act 1951 as disqualified.

anchor.surface_text: He was a candidate for the seat reserved for scheduled tribes. The numberination paper of the appellant was rejected by the returning officer on the ground that he was disqualified under s. 7 b  of the Representation

facts.text: Polling took place on February 25, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: of the People Act, No. XLIII of 1951,  hereinafter called the Act . The polling took place on February 25,1957,

facts.text: Khagendranath and Hkim Chandra Rabha elected, latter scheduled tribe member.

anchor.surface_text: and Khagendranath and Hkim Chandra Rabha were elected, the latter being a member of a scheduled tribe. Thereupon an election petition was filed by an elector

facts.text: Election petition filed by an elector challenging election of two successful candidates.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon an election petition was filed by an elector challenging the election of the two successful candidates on a number of grounds.

facts.text: Election tribunal held nomination paper of appellant improperly rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The election tribunal held on the, first point that the numberination paper of the appellant had been improperly rejected. On the second point it hold that the

facts.text: Election tribunal held corrupt practice not proved, set aside election.

anchor.surface_text: companyrupt practice alleged had number been proved. In the result, the election was set aside. Thereupon there was an appeal by the two successful candidates to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held nomination paper properly rejected, no corrupt practice, allowed appeal, dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the numberination paper of the appellant was properly rejected further on the question of companyrupt practice the High Court agreed with the companyclusion of the tribunal.

facts.text: Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal was allowed and the election petition was ordered to be dismissed. There was then an application to the High Court for a certificate to appeal

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s.4(b) Explosive Substances Act 1908, sentenced to 3 years RI on July 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in this case was companyvicted under s. 4 b  of the Explosive Substances Act No. VI of 1908, and sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment on July 10, 1953.

facts.text: Sentence remitted by Government of Assam on November 8, 1954 under s.401 CrPC, released November 14, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: But though the appellant was sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment, his sentence was remitted by the Government of Assam on November 8, 1954, under s. 401

facts.text: Appellant applied to Election Commission to remove disqualification, refused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had applied to the Election Commission for removing the disqualification but it had refused to do so.

facts.text: Supreme Court held remission does not reduce sentence for disqualification under s.7(b).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in the view that the numberination paper of the appellant was properly rejected.

facts.text: Voters carried on mechanically propelled vehicles to polling booths by Birendra Kumar Nath and Bholaram Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that voters were carried by mechanically propelled vehicles to the polling booths by Birendra Kumar Nath who was in-charge of the electioneering

anchor.surface_text: The numberination paper in this case was filed in January 1957 and the election was held in February 1957 and therefore five years had number elapsed since his release.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the nomination paper of the appellant was properly rejected under s. 7(b) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(b) disqualification based on court-imposed sentence of 3 years RI; remission under s.401 CrPC affects only execution, not the sentence itself; 5 years not elapsed since release.

holdings.text: An order of remission under s.401 CrPC does not reduce the sentence imposed by the court in the manner of an appellate or revisional court order, nor wipe out the conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The main question therefore that falls for companysideration is whether the order of remission has the effect of reducing the sentence in the same way in which an order of an appellate or revisional criminal companyrt has the effect of reducing the sentence passed by the trial companyrt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Remission is executive act suspending execution of sentence; conviction and judicial sentence remain intact; distinguished from pardon (wipes conviction) and judicial reduction; s.7(b) looks to court sentence, not time served.

holdings.text: A free pardon wipes out the offence, conviction, and all disqualifications; mere remission does not.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is number disputed that in England and India the effect of a pardon or what is sometimes called a free pardon is to clear the person from all infamy and from all companysequences of the offence for which it is granted and from all statutory or other disqualifications following upon companyviction. But the same effect does number follow on a mere remission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established common law and Indian position on pardon; remission merely affects execution, leaves judicial order untouched; supported by authorities like Halsbury.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice under s.100(1)(b) read with s.123(5) proved, as no consent, express or implied, of successful candidates established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agents' actions proved but no evidence of candidates' consent; s.100(1)(b) requires consent; concurrent findings of tribunal and High Court.

holdings.text: Whether consent existed is a question of fact based on inference from circumstances; concurrent findings thereon not interfereable in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this companycurrent finding of the High Court and the tribunal on this question, namely, whether there was companysent, express or implied, of the successful candidates to the companymission of this companyrupt practice, it is in our opinion idle for the appellant number to companytend that there was companysent express or implied, as required by s. 100 1  b . The inference whether there was companysent or number from the facts and circumstances proved is still an inference of fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference of consent is factual; supported by precedent (Meenakshi Mills); no basis to disturb concurrent findings.

holdings.text: Views in election cases like Ganda Singh v. Sampuran Singh incorrectly holding remission equivalent to judicial sentence reduction are wrong.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to a number of election cases in which the view which has been urged on behalf of the appellant seems to have been taken. We may refer to only one of them, namely, Ganda Singh v. Sampuran Singh ... We are of opinion that this view is incorrect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Those cases misapply distinction; remission not judicial reduction; Ganda Singh possibly involved pardon, not mere remission.

anchor.surface_text: We may refer to only one of them, namely, Ganda Singh v. Sampuran Singh 1 , which has specifically dealt with this point. In that case an order was passed by the Maharaja of Nabha granting amnesty to all political prisoners detained or convicted under the Punjab Public Safety Act, 1947, as applied to Nabha State, and releasing them unconditionally. The same order also provided for grant of remission to persons convicted for offences other than political offences on 1 1953 3 E.L.R. 17.

precedents.cited_proposition: remission by government executive authority has the same effect as an order passed by a court of law in appeal or on revision
precedents.cited_holding: under s. 7 of the Act the court has to look to the amount of sentence imposed on a person and it made no difference whether the sentence was reduced by a court of law on appeal or by revision or by the powers of the government reserved for it under s. 401 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

precedents.citation: Meenakshi Mills, Madurai v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this connection may be made to Meenakshi Mills, Madurai v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 , where it was held that a finding of fact, even when it is an inference from other facts found on evidence, is not a question of law and that such an inference can be a question of law only when the point for determination is a mixed question of law and fact.
